Package me.wobblyyyy.edt

Class DynamicArray<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.wobblyyyy.edt.DynamicArray<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of elements stored in the dynamic array.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Arrayable<E>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Analyzable, DynamicBoolean, DynamicDouble, DynamicFloat, DynamicInteger, DynamicString
    public class DynamicArray<E>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Arrayable<E>
    An implementation of the dynamic array concept commonly seen in computer science related fields. Although Java comes stock with several different implementations of dynamic arrays, most of these are rather abstract and, in turn, can lead to some performance losses.

    A dynamic array is an array that can be resized - meaning it can be grown, shrunk, etc - whatever you'd like. Regular Array instances in Java function fairly well already - they can store things and do tons of cool stuff, y'know?

    Other iterations and implementations of dynamic array concepts, such as the Vector class (which comes stock with the JDK) or even the ArrayList class (which also comes stock with the JDK) are already very effective. The DynamicArray class attempts to distinguish itself from other implementations of this concept by nearly quadrupling performance (in some cases) of large arrays by more liberally allocating memory to array elements. This will use a lot more memory than either of the two aforementioned data structures, however, performance is increased - ESPECIALLY on larger arrays. For more information regarding how performance is increased and the specific gains of performance, keep reading! You know you want to.

    At first glance, it would appear that the DynamicArray class is essentially the Vector class, which is already provided stock by Java. This is somewhat true - both are re-sizable/dynamic arrays. However, the DynamicArray class is better optimized for dealing with large sets of data.

    The performance gains provided by utilizing a DynamicArray over an ArrayList, for example, are rather noticeable. Performance tests for an array 100,000 in size indicate that a DynamicArray instance performs nearly 4x as fast as an ArrayList instance. These gains don't transfer over nearly as cleanly to lower throughput operations, however. As the DynamicArray can be effectively optimized for dealing with tons of data, it performs faster on huge arrays. The ArrayList gains a bit on the DynamicArray when it comes to speed with lower-array-size operations, but the DynamicArray should still outperform the ArrayList.

    Performance tests against an ArrayList reveal the following:

    • DynamicArray time: 1.456149E8
    • ArrayList time: 1.628252E8
    • Delta: DynamicArray is faster, by about 10%.
    This test was run by creating an empty DynamicArray and an empty ArrayList and forcing them to add 1000, 2000, and then 3000 objects to their arrays. Each array storage method had to dynamically allocate memory while adding these elements.

    The DynamicArray class is an effective replacement for the ArrayList class in many instances. Instances where using a dynamic array instead of an array list wouldn't be appropriate are limited, for the most part, to situations in which another method requires an array list as a parameter, rather than an array list. This issue can largely be circumvented by using the toArrayList() method, which will provide the DynamicArray as an array list, instead of a much less adopted DynamicArray instance.

    In addition to providing methods for adding, deleting, removing, whatever - whatever you want to call it - the DynamicArray class provides iteration functionality by leveraging the ArrayIterator sub-class. This class allows you to iterate over the entire data set quickly and without having to worry about setting up a for loop or whatever other fear you have. Look - I get it - for loops are incredibly scary and nobody really knows how to use them. For more information regarding iterating over elements stored in the DynamicArray, take a look at the iterator class and the JavaDoc documentation provided there.

    Author:
    Colin Robertson

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_SIZE

        private static final int DEFAULT_SIZE
        The default size of the dynamic array. We don't want to make this too big or too small. Going too big means we'll end up allocating more memory than we could ever even need, and going to small means we'll end up having to grow the array very quickly.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • EMPTY

        private static final java.lang.Object[] EMPTY
        An empty object array. Whenever a DynamicArray instance is created without any input values, the DynamicArray uses this value as the element value.

      • _itr_internal_

        private final ArrayIterator<E> _itr_internal_
        The internally-used iterator. This iterator is instanced upon the creation of the DynamicArray and can not be interacted with, aside from getting it, using the itr() method.

      • activeSize

        private int activeSize
        The size of the currently-active portion of the array. Because this DynamicArray class doesn't grow and shrink the array whenever elements are added or removed in order to conserve processing power, the active size of the array almost never matches the size of the element array - where objects are actually stored.

      • minSize

        private int minSize
        The array's minimum size. This is used mostly in optimization for very large arrays - say you have a DynamicArray instance that you know will need to store thousands of objects. The minimum size of the DynamicArray can be set somewhere in the thousands to prevent having to grow the DynamicArray frequently.

      • elements

        private java.lang.Object[] elements
        All of the elements stored and used within the DynamicArray instance. These elements are updated and queried via methods provided in this class.

    • Constructor Detail

      • DynamicArray

        public DynamicArray()
        Create a new DynamicArray instance without any values or elements. Because there are no values or elements inserted into the array at construction, the array will be entirely empty. New values and elements can be added to the DynamicArray using any of the insertion or append methods provided in this class.
        See Also:
        add(Object), add(Object[]), add(int, Object)

      • DynamicArray

        @SafeVarargs
public DynamicArray​(E... elements)
        Create a new DynamicArray instance using a plain array of elements as the initialization elements. These elements can be updated later with the methods provided in the DynamicArray class.
        Parameters:
        elements - an array, containing all of the Object instances that should be set as the DynamicArray's contents upon construction.

      • DynamicArray

        public DynamicArray​(int minSize)
        Create a new DynamicArray instance without any data. Instead of data, we have a lovely integer, representing the minimum allocation size of the array. This allocation size can be used to boost performance. Allocating a larger size uses more memory but reduces CPU time when dealing with arrays of that size of slightly smaller.
        Parameters:
        minSize - the minimum size of the array. By default, this value is 10. Larger arrays can have sizes up to 10,000, 100,000, or even 1,000,000 - it's entirely up to you.

      • DynamicArray

        public DynamicArray​(int minSize,
                    java.lang.Object[] elements)
        Create a new DynamicArray instance using a plain array of elements as the initialization elements. These elements can be updated later with the methods provided in the DynamicArray class.
        Parameters:
        minSize - the minimum size of the array.
        elements - an array, containing all of the Object instances that should be set as the DynamicArray's contents upon construction.

      • DynamicArray

        public DynamicArray​(java.util.ArrayList<E> elements)
        Create a new DynamicArray instance by using an ArrayList instance to provide initialization values for the newly-constructed array.
        Parameters:
        elements - an ArrayList of elements that should be set to the dynamic array's contents. These elements must be of the same type the newly-created DynamicArray is of.

      • DynamicArray

        public DynamicArray​(Arrayable<E> arrayable)
        Create a new DynamicArray instance by using an Arrayable object as the "base" that the dynamic array should be based on. This can be useful when converting a static array to a dynamic array.
        Parameters:
        arrayable - the array object that should be the base of the new dynamic array. Ex: StaticArray instance.

    • Method Detail

      • getOobException

        private static java.lang.String getOobException​(boolean h,
                                                int index,
                                                int size)
        Get an out-of-bounds exception message based on a given index and whether that index was too low or too high.
        Parameters:
        h - if that index was too low or if it was too high. A state of true indicates that the index was too low, while a state of false indicates that the index was too high.
        index - the index that is out of bounds.
        size - the maximum allowable size / index.
        Returns:
        a String message that can be thrown as an exception by another calling method. In this case, the calling method of this method is almost always checkIndex(int).

      • checkIndex

        public boolean checkIndex​(int index)
        Check a given index to see if it is within the allowable range of minimum and maximum index values. If it isn't, throw an exception indicating that the specified index is invalid.
        Specified by:
        checkIndex in interface Arrayable<E>
        Parameters:
        index - the index to check.
        Returns:
        true if the index is contained in the active size of the array. False if the index isn't contained in the active size of the array.

      • checkIndices

        private void checkIndices​(int[] indices)
        Check an array of index values by using the (provided elsewhere) checkIndex(int) method for the highest and lowest index values. This operation can be expensive, as it requires the array to be sorted before checking values.
        Parameters:
        indices - an array of the index values to check.

        Parameters:
        minimum - the minimum size of the array.
        Returns:
        a new size for the array.

      • add

        public void add​(E[] values)
        Add an array of elements to the DynamicArray's internal list of elements.

        These elements are, by default, appended to the end of the dynamic array. If you'd like to control where the elements go, you can use... add(int, Object)

        Parameters:
        values - the values that should be appended to the DynamicArray instance's elements array.
        See Also:
        add(int, Object), add(Object)

      • add

        public void add​(E value)
        Add a value to the end of the DynamicArray's internal array of elements. If the array isn't large enough to support the requested operation, the array will be grown by a factor that allows the array to support the requested operation.
        Parameters:
        value - the value that should be appended to the end of the DynamicArray's element array.
        See Also:
        add(Object[]), add(int, Object)

      • add

        public void add​(int index,
                E value)
        Add a value to the DynamicArray's internal array of elements. If the array isn't large enough to support the requested operation, the array will be grown by a factor that allows the array to support the requested operation.

        Unlike the add(Object) method, this method gives you control over the index of where the element is inserted. This method will split the array in half and insert the value you requested at the index you specified.

        Parameters:
        index - the target index for the specified value.
        value - the value to set to the index.
        See Also:
        add(Object[]), add(Object)

      • remove

        public void remove()
        Remove the last-added element from the dynamic array. This simply removes the element that's at the array's end point.

        If the current active size of the DynamicArray is already too small to remove another element from, nothing happens and this method simply... well... doesn't do anything. Yeah. That's all.

        See Also:
        remove(int), remove(int[]), removeAfter(int)

      • remove

        public void remove​(int[] indices)
        Remove a set of values based on an array of index targets. Each of the values for each of the corresponding index targets will be removed from the DynamicArray's register of elements.

        This method is rather expensive, and, preferably, should be avoided if at all possible. This isn't to say that it won't work, or that it's a slow method - it's still blazing fast, but by comparison to the rest of the DynamicArray methods, this one is a bit slower.

        Parameters:
        indices - all the index targets to be removed.
        See Also:
        remove(), remove(int), removeAfter(int)

      • remove

        public void remove​(int index)
        Remove a value from a specified index in the DynamicArray's internal array of elements.
        Parameters:
        index - the index that should have its corresponding value removed from existence.
        See Also:
        remove(), remove(int[]), removeAfter(int)

      • removeAfter

        public void removeAfter​(int cutoff)
        Remove any elements after a specified cutoff index. Any element after this point will be removed from the active array's data.
        Parameters:
        cutoff - the cutoff point. Any element after this point will be removed from the DynamicArray's active area.
        See Also:
        remove(int[]), remove(), remove(int)

      • set

        public void set​(int index,
                E value)
        Set a value at a specific index.

        Unlike the add(Object) methods provided in this class, this method will not add anything to the array. Rather, it will simply set a value.

        Specified by:
        set in interface Arrayable<E>
        Parameters:
        index - the index that should be set.
        value - the value to set to the given index.

      • get

        public E get​(int index)
        Get a value from the DynamicArray based on a provided index.

        Before returning the specified value, check to see if the given index is valid using the checkIndex(int) method. If the index is out of bounds, we throw an ArrayIndexOutOfBounds exception, indicating that the requested index is invalid.

        Specified by:
        get in interface Arrayable<E>
        Parameters:
        index - the index to query a value from.
        Returns:
        the value that comes from the index. If the index is out of the array's bounds, we don't do anything - an exception is thrown anyways, so we don't need to return anything.
        See Also:
        get(int[])

      • get

        public E[] get​(int[] indices)
        Get an array of values based on an array of indices to query.

        Before returning the specified value, check to see if the given index is valid using the checkIndex(int) method. If the index is out of bounds, we throw an ArrayIndexOutOfBounds exception, indicating that the requested index is invalid.

        Parameters:
        indices - all of the indices to query the value of.
        Returns:
        an array of the same size as the size of the input index array. If no values are found, or no values are added, an empty array is returned - that is, assuming there weren't any exceptions.
        See Also:
        get(int)

      • indexOf

        public int indexOf​(E query)
        Get the index of a specified element. This method searches the entire active array and attempts to find the index of the first instance of that object. If that object is stored in the array multiple times, only the first index will be returned.

        This method uses the indexOfInRange(Object, int, int) method to determine the index of a given object within a certain range. This method is essentially an overload - we use the default range of the array, which is zero (array start) to the array's maximum.

        Specified by:
        indexOf in interface Arrayable<E>
        Parameters:
        query - the element to query. This element should be exactly the same as any of the elements that may be found. If this element isn't the same as any of the elements contained in the DynamicArray, we return -1.
        Returns:
        if the queried element is contained within the predefined range of (0) to (array max), return the index of the first instance of the queried element. If the queried element is not contained within the given range, return -1.
        See Also:
        indexOfInRange(Object, int, int)

      • indexOfInRange

        public int indexOfInRange​(E query,
                          int min,
                          int max)
        Get the index of a specified element, so long as it fits within that range. If the element does not fit within that range, the element is ignored, and thus, the index is ignored as well.
        Parameters:
        query - the element to query. This element should be the same element as the requested one. If it isn't, nothing will be found. If it is, the index will be returned.
        min - the minimum index that should be searched. By default, this is zero.
        max - the maximum index that should be searched. By default, this is the length of the DynamicArray.
        Returns:
        if the queried element is contained in the range, return the index of that queried element. If the queried element is not in the range, however, return -1.
        See Also:
        indexOf(Object)

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Check to see if the entire DynamicArray is empty. The DynamicArray being empty is defined by the active size of the array being equal to zero.
        Specified by:
        isEmpty in interface Arrayable<E>
        Returns:
        whether or not the DynamicArray is entirely empty.
        See Also:
        size()

      • contains

        public boolean contains​(E query)
        Check to see if the DynamicArray contains any instances of the queried element. If an instance of the element is found, this method will return true. If no instances of the element are found, this method will return false.

        This method works by attempting to find the index of the queried element. If the index is -1, we know the element isn't contained in the array, and we return false. If the index is 0 or above, however, we know that the element is contained somewhere in the array - thus, we return true.

        Specified by:
        contains in interface Arrayable<E>
        Parameters:
        query - the element to query.
        Returns:
        true if the queried element is found inside of the DynamicArray at some point, false if it isn't.
        See Also:
        indexOf(Object), isEmpty()

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Clear all of the values contained in the active portion of the array.

        It's important to note that this method WILL NOT re-size the array. The active portion of the DynamicArray will still be whatever it was before. This method will, however, set all of the elements in the active portion of the array to be equal to null.

        See Also:
        clearAndTrim(), trim(), reset()

      • clearAndTrim

        public void clearAndTrim()
        This method will do exactly what these two methods normally do.

        • clear()
        • trim()

        In case it matters at all: The array will be cleared before it is trimmed. This shouldn't impact much, but yeah. There you go.

        See Also:
        clear(), trim(), reset()

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Reset the entire array. Unlike the clear method, this method will actually reset the size of the array to zero and clear each and every one of the elements that was originally contained in it.
        See Also:
        clear(), clearAndTrim(), trim()

      • trim

        public void trim()
        Trim the currently-stored element array into a smaller element array by reducing the size of the array to the active size of the array.

        Array elements aren't always wiped from the array whenever that element is removed. In order to optimize performance, these values are often left alone until they're no longer needed. However, if you would like to cut down on memory usage, using this method will allow you to reduce the memory footprint of the DynamicArray by trimming any values that aren't actively being used by the array.

        See Also:
        reset(), clear(), clearAndTrim()

      • toList

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Object> toList()
        Convert this instance of a DynamicArray into an instance of the much more well-known List.
        Specified by:
        toList in interface Arrayable<E>
        Returns:
        a converted DynamicArray that has been transformed into a list. Not an array list!
        See Also:
        toArray(), toArrayList()

      • toArrayList

        public java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Object> toArrayList()
        Convert this instance of a DynamicArray into an instance of an ArrayList. This method calls the toArray() method in order to convert the internal facing array into an external facing one, and then creates a new ArrayList instance based on the converted array.
        Specified by:
        toArrayList in interface Arrayable<E>
        Returns:
        a newly-created ArrayList instance, composed of the same elements as the calling DynamicArray.
        See Also:
        toArray(), toList()

      • size

        public int size()
        Get the size of the active portion of the element array.
        Specified by:
        size in interface Arrayable<E>
        Returns:
        the size of the active portion of the element array.
        See Also:
        activeSize

      • realSize

        public int realSize()
        Get the real size of the DynamicArray. The (very lovely) size() method will return the size of the active portion of the array, while this method will return the size of the entire element array.
        Returns:
        the size of the entire element array.
        See Also:
        activeSize

      • toArray

        public java.lang.Object[] toArray()
        Convert this instance of a DynamicArray into a plain array instance by creating a clone of the elements contained in the calling instance that is the same size as the active size.

        The internally-stored array is often larger than the external-facing array for performance reasons - although it uses more memory, it takes less CPU power to store un-used array values even when they aren't accessible to the user. This means that the returned array here isn't exactly the same as the array that's used inside of this class.

        Specified by:
        toArray in interface Arrayable<E>
        Returns:
        the elements of the DynamicArray, in array form. This is a new array, not the same array - you can't modify this array and expect the values contained in the internally-used array to be updated, as this method is intentionally immutable.
        See Also:
        toArrayList(), toList(), toDoubleArray(), toIntegerArray()

      • toArray

        public E[] toArray​(E[] base)
        Get the array of objects contained in the DynamicArray and cast them into a given array. Please note: number types CAN NOT be cast here. In order to get an array of numbers, you need to use the methods linked in the see tags of this method.
        Specified by:
        toArray in interface Arrayable<E>
        Parameters:
        base - the base array - this array will be over-written by a copied array, originating from the internal array.
        Returns:
        the internally-stored array of elements, cast into a given array of the type E.
        See Also:
        toDoubleArray(), toIntegerArray()

      • toDoubleArray

        public java.lang.Double[] toDoubleArray()
        Get the DynamicArray's internal array and cast it into a number array. This method is rather expensive, as it has to manually unbox each of the objects contained inside of the array.
        Specified by:
        toDoubleArray in interface Arrayable<E>
        Returns:
        a pre-casted array of double elements.
        See Also:
        toIntegerArray()

      • toIntegerArray

        public java.lang.Integer[] toIntegerArray()
        Get the DynamicArray's internal array and cast it into a number array. This method is rather expensive, as it has to manually unbox each of the objects contained inside of the array.
        Specified by:
        toIntegerArray in interface Arrayable<E>
        Returns:
        a pre-casted array of integer elements.
        See Also:
        toDoubleArray()

      • itr

        public ItrSingle<E> itr()
        Get the DynamicArray's iterator nested class. The iterator class provides iteration functionality for the DynamicArray data structure. Documentation on the iterator class's functionality is available in the iterator class itself - take a look at the "see" tags on this JavaDoc if you're confused.
        Specified by:
        itr in interface Arrayable<E>
        Returns:
        this DynamicArray's iterator nested class. This class is generated at the DynamicArray's construction and does not need to be maintained or interacted with other than to iterate over the array of elements.
